item.description: Setting it up each time is probably a hassle. Overall, I don't think it's very suitable for making cheats or cracks.

item.title: @mojtabafaaleh on 2025-09-07 01:25:30+00:00 (#10621)
item.description: Yeah, it's possible you can write a script for the !monitor command using HyperDbg.

item.description: It seems that hyper has no function similar to ce dbvm cloak?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-07 00:10:51+00:00 (#10619)
item.description: I only use its monitoring address function, and at the same time return all attempts to access this address to a fake memory address, similar to ce dbvm cloak

item.title: @mojtabafaaleh on 2025-09-02 23:03:17+00:00 (#10612)
item.description: It has an SDK that you can use to modify it for your own purposes, but due to the complexities of the hypervisor, I don't think it's very easy to work with it like a regular debugger.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-02 22:58:17+00:00 (#10611)
item.description: Is it convenient to use? Do you need to modify anything else?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-02 22:58:02+00:00 (#10610)
item.description: Does anyone know how to change this source code into their own private tool? For example, only for a certain process

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-09-02 16:51:18+00:00 (#10609)
item.description: Yes indeed, SubEPT is deprecated now

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-09-02 16:50:26+00:00 (#10608)
item.description:
[discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: I wish intel would support write only ept pages.
Also it looks like sub paging permissions of ept is going to be removed in the future
https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/developer/articles/technical/software-security-guidance/advisory-guidance/sub-page-permission.html
`Intel plans to discontinue SPP entirely on future processors`

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-02 16:30:03+00:00 (#10607)
item.description: Yes, it works well. If it just monitors reading and writing, it doesn't cause vm to quit. Now I'm trying to sign your dll separately so that it doesn't need to use test mode.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 13:35:03+00:00 (#10606)
item.description: Yes. The main implementation EPT hooks for instructions in HyperDbg is the '!epthook' command which supports both user-mode and kernel-mode pages. The second implementation of EPT hooks (the '!epthook2' command) only supports kernel-mode pages (not user-mode).

item.title: @montagne1337 on 2025-09-02 13:25:22+00:00 (#10605)
item.description: can the same be said about user pages?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 12:12:10+00:00 (#10604)
item.description: Yes, it fundamentally doesn't have such a issue based on its design.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 12:11:47+00:00 (#10603)
item.description: It might be changes from the EPT page table view but for kernel, it remains the same.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 12:11:29+00:00 (#10602)
item.description: HyperDbg uses an identity map memory layout, which means the addresses wouldn't be changed from the perspective of the kernel memory (regular page table).

item.title: @montagne1337 on 2025-09-02 11:44:10+00:00 (#10601)
item.description: does '!epthook' resolve RIP relative instructions?

item.title: @montagne1337 on 2025-09-02 11:41:54+00:00 (#10600)
item.description: for example I hooked nt!ExAllocatePool , which is located at virtual address 0x500A540 , I created a copy of the original page containing bytes from 0x500A000 to 0x500AFFF , and set my hook on the copy page + 0x540. When an ept violation occurs and the exit qualification is execute access, the ept handler replaces the original PFN with the PFN of my copied page. Now, what if, for example, on the page where nt!ExAllocatePool is located, there was some relative jmp or relative call instruction or any other RIP relative instruction, I just blindly copied it, and now, if it is executed, it will lead to a garbage address.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 11:30:51+00:00 (#10599)
item.description: So I think in your use case, there wouldn't be any performance degradation.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 11:30:10+00:00 (#10598)
item.description: Intel supports execute-only page tables, which means that if you monitor for Read/Write but the page is only executed, there‚Äôs no performance penalty since no VM-exit occurs. However, on Intel processors, if you monitor only for Write, a Read access will still trigger a VM-exit. HyperDbg silently handles and ignores these events, but they do introduce some overhead.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 11:26:56+00:00 (#10597)
item.description: Or am I misunderstanding the question?

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 11:26:39+00:00 (#10596)
item.description: So, if you just use '!epthook' it should be fine with all relative instructions.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-02 11:26:20+00:00 (#10595)
item.description: If you mean the '!epthook2' command, then no. It doesn't fix RIP relative instructions (and I think it is also mentioned in the documentation) but for the main EPT hook ('!epthook'), this is not a problem.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-02 08:54:12+00:00 (#10593)
item.description: It doesn't have any visits. But it is frequently executed, so execution and reading and writing are two different things?

item.title: @montagne1337 on 2025-09-02 06:43:06+00:00 (#10592)
item.description: hey there, does HyperDbg fix RIP relative instructions for the page where the ept hook is applied? I noticed that if some relative jmp or call is executed inside the copied page, it leads to a garbage address

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-01 23:26:13+00:00 (#10591)
item.description: I mean, HyperDbg's !monitor command is super fast. In almost all cases, you won't even notice the system slowing down. If the page is something special that's accessed hundreds of times each second, it might slow the system down. Otherwise, it should be fine.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-01 23:23:26+00:00 (#10590)
item.description: You can configure HyperDbg (from visual studio) to sign it with the test sign if it helps.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-01 23:15:10+00:00 (#10589)
item.description: I wonder if I use hyper to monitor only the memory reading and writing of an address, will it take up a lot of cpu? And this address is not frequently read and written by memory, only once every few minutes, but it is frequently executed. I want to do crc3 protection.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-01 23:13:57+00:00 (#10588)
item.description: Yes, unless you have a certificate, you must use test mode.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-09-01 13:32:07+00:00 (#10587)
item.description: Test mode? Running HyperDbg in test mode of Windows?

item.description: https://docs.hyperdbg.org/getting-started/build-and-install

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-01 13:01:50+00:00 (#10585)
item.description: Can this only be started in test mode?

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-09-01 13:01:34+00:00 (#10584)
item.description: You're right.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-08-31 23:00:37+00:00 (#10583)
item.description: @getting458 Let's try to keep the discussions on-topic to benefit everyone here. Appreciate your understanding!

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-08-30 12:44:38+00:00 (#10578)
item.description: It's a bit tricky. If the modification rate is too high, it might make the system unresponsive and slow it down. But in general, you can put a monitor hook on the entire buffer address range, no matter how big it is.

item.title: @getting458 on 2025-08-30 12:40:49+00:00 (#10577)
item.description: cool

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 15:40:03+00:00 (#10567)

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 15:36:17+00:00 (#10566)
item.description: [discord] <honorary_bot> Good morning, @unrustled.jimmies ! I figured out what was going on with my xsetbv handler. And it's not the compiler. It's me, as usual. It all started when I decided that I need to regroup my status codes for consistency with PulseEng library. I changed status codes almost a YEAR ago. It turns out that I failed to update status codes in my asm routines, so they were still spitting old status codes that would not match with C code anymore. The xsetbv handler was OK all along, it was just taking unexpected status values from AsmXsetbv proc. With that said, do you mind checking the fix whenever convenient for you? https://pulsedbg.com/files/test/uj.zip

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 09:17:35+00:00 (#10565)
item.description: [discord] <territory3351> [reply]: Yeah, it gives me a headache.üò©

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 09:13:23+00:00 (#10564)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: x2apic and vmexiting on all MSRs sounds like a recipe for disaster especially when it does the real wrmsr in vmx root with a custom IDT.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 08:49:22+00:00 (#10563)
item.description: [discord] <territory3351> Writemsr 0x80B will cause a crash. Why doesn't MsrHandleWrmsrVmexit use TestBit to filter MSR exceptions like MsrHandleRdmsrVmexit does? https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1408010078316924978/image.png?ex=68a82f12&is=68a6dd92&hm=e4cdfc051fbb1bc81e2a9c8cd3d3b9b413e5142ee90c2dd9ada8fd80f7ff14d1&

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 08:49:22+00:00 (#10562)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: good luck!

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-21 08:41:14+00:00 (#10561)
item.description: Same here. Gotta load IDA and investigate every piece of code with exception handlers

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-21 08:40:30+00:00 (#10560)
item.description: Yes, that‚Äôs my concern as well

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 08:38:06+00:00 (#10559)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> my concern is where else is this happening.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 08:37:21+00:00 (#10558)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: im guessing the compiler cant make the connection that the RIP can be made to return those 2 negative values since it happens in the #GP. all it sees is it could return 0.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-21 08:36:23+00:00 (#10557)
item.description: So, it does indeed optimize out a critical piece of the handler. And I probably understand why. I think there is a major oversight in my root vm exit handler. That‚Äôs a big one to catch, thank you!

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 08:31:52+00:00 (#10556)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> nope, i can try now

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 08:30:54+00:00 (#10555)

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-08-21 08:03:47+00:00 (#10550)
item.description: HyperDbg doesn't support nested-virtualization. You could run HyperDbg on a nested virtualization environment like VMware but HyperDbg itself doesn't allow you to have another hypervisor.

It skips over 7 or 18 bytes for GP or UD. 7 and 18 bytes are exactly these 2 functions. https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1407996592014884886/Screenshot_2025-08-21_005413.png?ex=68a82282&is=68a6d102&hm=53ddadba450c7c2468e7752ee3f6f943d0ab86d71521c379905dffce06f5c90b&

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 07:42:33+00:00 (#10539)
item.description: [discord] <territory3351> Excuse me, what should I pay attention to when using BroadcastChangeAllMsrBitmapWriteAllCores(DEBUGGER_EVENT_MSR_READ_OR_WRITE_ALL_MSRS)? Why does it have a blue screen in the physical machine?

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-21 07:41:22+00:00 (#10538)
item.description:
[discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: I took a quick look into this.
I think you just need to validate the XCR as per the SDM. (in this sample case xcr is 0x7FFFFFFF). But since you execute xsetbv within the context of a #GP/#UD handler that just skips over the bytes of the instruction to a function that returns an error code, you could use that as the signal whether to re-inject a #UD/#GP into the guest as well instead of emulating all the checks. https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1407992966198464584/Screenshot_2025-08-21_001447.png?ex=68a81f22&is=68a6cda2&hm=8c4513041963856cf677ed69157183e043d366093ee49aa7cc0197947c4c50bc&

item.title: @8009141197 on 2025-08-21 03:46:17+00:00 (#10537)
item.description: Hello, HyperDbg is something really great that I‚Äôve just started exploring. I know it always tries hard to hide itself, such as against anti-hypervisor techniques. I have a question: if an anti-cheat software also needs to use VT-x, does that mean I can‚Äôt use HyperDbg anymore? Can‚Äôt they coexist?

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-20 23:18:59+00:00 (#10535)
item.description: Thanks for the finding, I'll check that one

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-20 23:04:24+00:00 (#10534)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: Hey, i totally forgot, i had to patch pulsedbg as well for xsetbv (it wasn't detecting it as a handled vmexit (even tho it did try to handle it so not sure why) so i just patched out the check that errored out if the vmexit was unhandled). this was just a quick thing i was testing that i never got back to (i can try to repro if you want). https://cdn.discordapp.com/attachments/962350355839066130/1407862866396315759/Screenshot_2025-08-20_155944.png?ex=68a7a5f8&is=68a65478&hm=9265daec18a0cfff7d394427ea58918b942d6d7f48abbbc5cd656a16f36c18df&

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-08-20 23:01:53+00:00 (#10533)
item.description: I think for HyperDbg it would be more of detecting anti-hypervisor methods.

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-08-20 23:01:25+00:00 (#10532)
item.description: Oh, okay. Thanks for the explanation.

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-20 22:56:06+00:00 (#10531)
item.description: xsetbv is for the os to enable or disable certain extended features

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-20 22:55:29+00:00 (#10530)
item.description: f.e. avx512 may be implemented and show up in cpuid, but disabled in xcr0

item.title: @honorary_bot on 2025-08-20 22:54:52+00:00 (#10529)
item.description: xgetbv is used to detect which extended features are currently enabled, accessible right from the usermode

item.title: @HughEverett on 2025-08-20 22:46:35+00:00 (#10528)
item.description: oh, okay üëç

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-20 22:45:31+00:00 (#10526)
item.description: [discord] <unrustled.jimmies> [reply]: Its more used to detect hypervisors like cpuid/rdtsc as far as im aware since its an unconditional vm exit. not aware of any actual purpose functionality wise (in the context of HVs). as an actual x86 instruction, yeah i never really looked into it from this angle.

item.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2025-08-20 16:46:58+00:00 (#10516)
@HughEverett on 2025-08-20 16:17:04+00:00 (#10515)
item.description: Check this example: https://youtu.be/PX38N5F3SL8?t=242
